docs.text: Welcome to Classes documentation! ¶ Github Code ¶ FiveM post ¶ Patch Notes ¶ v0.1.0 BIG CHANGES ¶ Find a new method of creating classes, old method had bugs about being replaced it-self. v0.1.1 ¶ Added StateBag class Fix [client/ped.lua] missing returning the Vehicle class v0.1.2 ¶ Added new class Prop Added inside class methods .state It's used like class StateBag (ex: .state:set(key, value, shared)) v0.1.3 ¶ Added method AddBlip to Coords class Added methods GetPosition and SwapModel to class Prop Added function TimeoutRequestModel to utils Added common methods (string and table) Removed error when trying to create a Ped class with non existent entity (now is only a warning) Updated state for Player class Updated StateBag for players
docs.title: Index

docs.text: Find a new method of creating classes, old method had bugs about being replaced it-self.
docs.title: v0.1.0 BIG CHANGES

docs.text: Added StateBag class Fix [client/ped.lua] missing returning the Vehicle class
docs.title: v0.1.1

docs.text: Added new class Prop Added inside class methods .state It's used like class StateBag (ex: .state:set(key, value, shared))
docs.title: v0.1.2

docs.text: Added method AddBlip to Coords class Added methods GetPosition and SwapModel to class Prop Added function TimeoutRequestModel to utils Added common methods (string and table) Removed error when trying to create a Ped class with non existent entity (now is only a warning) Updated state for Player class Updated StateBag for players
docs.title: v0.1.3

docs.text: Creating your first script with classes ! ¶ Create your resource folder ¶ In this case, my resource will be named tutorial Your directory will look like this: tutorial | fxmanifest.lua | +---client | main.lua | \---server main.lua Let's import the classes to our resource! ¶ Inside your fxmanifest.lua fx_version 'cerulean' games { 'gta5' } client_scripts { '@classes/common/utils.lua' , '@classes/client/utils.lua' , '@classes/client/statebag.lua' , '@classes/client/coords.lua' , '@classes/client/vehicle.lua' , '@classes/client/player.lua' , '@classes/client/ped.lua' , '@classes/client/marker.lua' , 'client/main.lua' } server_scripts { '@classes/common/utils.lua' , '@classes/server/utils.lua' , '@classes/server/statebag.lua' , '@classes/server/coords.lua' , '@classes/server/vehicle.lua' , '@classes/server/player.lua' , '@classes/server/ped.lua' , 'server/main.lua' } dependency 'classes' -- if we want to use ESX --[[ dependencies { 'classes', 'es_extended' } ]] Adding this to snippets for VSCode ¶ Adding a snippet on VSCode to write our fxmanifest.lua file will be very useful. Go to File > Preferences > User Snippets Create a New Global Snippets file... Remove all from the snippet file Copy and paste this inside the snippet file: { "fxmanifest" :{ "scope" : "lua" , "prefix" : "fxmanifest" , "body" : [ "fx_version 'cerulean'" , "games { 'gta5' }" , "" , "client_scripts {" , "\t'@classes/common/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/statebag.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/coords.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/vehicle.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/player.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/ped.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/marker.lua'," , "\t'client/*.lua'," , "}" , "" , "server_scripts {" , "\t'@classes/common/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/statebag.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/coords.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/vehicle.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/player.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/ped.lua'," , "\t'server/*.lua'," , "}" , "" , "dependency 'classes'" ] }, } Once this is done, we just need to write fxmanifest and press enter.
docs.title: How to start
Creating your first script with classes!

docs.text: In this case, my resource will be named tutorial Your directory will look like this: tutorial | fxmanifest.lua | +---client | main.lua | \---server main.lua
docs.title: Create your resource folder

docs.text: Inside your fxmanifest.lua fx_version 'cerulean' games { 'gta5' } client_scripts { '@classes/common/utils.lua' , '@classes/client/utils.lua' , '@classes/client/statebag.lua' , '@classes/client/coords.lua' , '@classes/client/vehicle.lua' , '@classes/client/player.lua' , '@classes/client/ped.lua' , '@classes/client/marker.lua' , 'client/main.lua' } server_scripts { '@classes/common/utils.lua' , '@classes/server/utils.lua' , '@classes/server/statebag.lua' , '@classes/server/coords.lua' , '@classes/server/vehicle.lua' , '@classes/server/player.lua' , '@classes/server/ped.lua' , 'server/main.lua' } dependency 'classes' -- if we want to use ESX --[[ dependencies { 'classes', 'es_extended' } ]]
docs.title: Let's import the classes to our resource!

docs.text: Adding a snippet on VSCode to write our fxmanifest.lua file will be very useful. Go to File > Preferences > User Snippets Create a New Global Snippets file... Remove all from the snippet file Copy and paste this inside the snippet file: { "fxmanifest" :{ "scope" : "lua" , "prefix" : "fxmanifest" , "body" : [ "fx_version 'cerulean'" , "games { 'gta5' }" , "" , "client_scripts {" , "\t'@classes/common/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/statebag.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/coords.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/vehicle.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/player.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/ped.lua'," , "\t'@classes/client/marker.lua'," , "\t'client/*.lua'," , "}" , "" , "server_scripts {" , "\t'@classes/common/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/utils.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/statebag.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/coords.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/vehicle.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/player.lua'," , "\t'@classes/server/ped.lua'," , "\t'server/*.lua'," , "}" , "" , "dependency 'classes'" ] }, } Once this is done, we just need to write fxmanifest and press enter.
docs.title: Adding this to snippets for VSCode

docs.text: AddBlip ¶ Parameters ¶ blip sprite number as short range boolean optional blip name string optional scale number optional color number optional alpha number optional Returns ¶ the blip id number Raise ¶ error the sprite id wasn't a number Examples ¶ local coords = Coords ( GetEntityCoords ( PlayerPedId ())) coords : AddBlip ( 1 , true , 'awesome blip' , 0.6 , 1 , 255 )
docs.title: AddBlip

docs.text: blip sprite number as short range boolean optional blip name string optional scale number optional color number optional alpha number optional
docs.title: Parameters

docs.text: the blip id number
docs.title: Returns

docs.text: error the sprite id wasn't a number
docs.title: Raise

docs.text: local coords = Coords ( GetEntityCoords ( PlayerPedId ())) coords : AddBlip ( 1 , true , 'awesome blip' , 0.6 , 1 , 255 )
docs.title: Examples

docs.text: Coords ¶ Parameters ¶ x number y number z number w number Or any vector vector2 / vector3 / vector4 Returns ¶ object Coords Raise ¶ error None of the parameters are number or vector Examples ¶ local spawnPoint = Coords ( 34.9 , 456.1 , 15.3 , 100.0 ) local spawnPoint = Coords ( GetEntityCoords ( PlayerPedId ()))

docs.text: TimeoutRequestModel ¶ Parameters ¶ model string / number Returns ¶ model loaded boolean Raise ¶ warning After 500ms, request timed out. This breaks the loop waiting for the model. Examples ¶ if TimeoutRequestModel ( 'cheetah' ) then -- create vehicle cheetah end

docs.text: string:split ¶ Parameters ¶ pattern string Returns ¶ iterator function Raise ¶ None Examples ¶ local my_string = 'classes is an awesome script!' for word in my_string : split () do -- stuff print ( word ) end for word in ( "classes is an awesome script!" ): split () do -- stuff print ( word ) end

docs.text: table.dump ¶ !!! note This is not a json encoder! Parameters ¶ table to dump table Returns ¶ dumped table string Raise ¶ None Examples ¶ print ( table . dump ( table . build (( "classes are awesome!" ): split ()) ) ) local my_table = { key = 'awesome value' , key2 = 'classes are awesome' , key3 = { foo = 'bar' } } print ( table . dump ( my_table ) )
docs.title: table.dump
